Respect is a feeling of admiration for others on account of their abilities, qualities or achievements. It can also mean having a due regard for the feelings, wishes, rights, or customs of others. 
 
 Last year, the British government announced it had a Respect Agenda and set up a task force to promote "respect" in society as a means of reducing anti-social behaviour - especially among violent and aggressive young men. It doesn't seem to have had any effect. 
 
 The particular idea that respect as a social value can be enforced by government decree is obviously ridiculous. But are we all entitled to a presumption of "automatic respect" from others? Doesn't respect have to be earned?

 In the case of your second sentence then no it doesn't have to be earned, but then again it doesn't have precisely the same connotation
 
 Oh and yes, this Agenda thing was another of the generally useless sound bites and grandstanding of Blair's government

Shouldn't disrespect have to be earned?
 
 I try to practice common courtesy in order to allow people a chance to earn my respect. People who won't do likewise deserve a spanking. Fear is the next best thing to respect or is it the other way around?

There is a difference between treating someone with respect and actually respecting them. The British government seems to be supporting a policy of respect in that they would like people to treat each other with respect. I would support them in such a policy. They certainly cannot dictate that people actually feel respect for others, in the sense of admiring or even agreeing with them, and I don't think that they are trying to do that.
 
 The whole political correctness movement was aimed at promoting such respectful treatment, or at least discouraging disrespect. One can certainly argue that the PC movement has gone way too far in discouraging any discussion of differences between groups of people whatsoever, but you would have to admit that the world is a better place since it has become socially unacceptable to use words such as nigger, spic, kike, etc. I am fully supportive of efforts on the British government side of discouraging any such generalized disrespectful treatment.

Respect involving admiration cannot be legislated. Respect involving leaving people alone to do their own thing may be capable of being legislated.
 
 The government cannot order me to respect (admire) anyone or anything.
 
 The government can order me to respect (not interfere with) everyone's right to free speech or to drink from the village fountain. It cannot force me to like or respect any one person.
 
 I admire their effort to promote respect, but think it futile to order it done.

Why do people keep talking about the government "forcing", "ordering", or "legislating" respect? Nothing in the first post suggests that's what's happening here. All is says is that the government is promoting respect. That could just mean ad campaigns, etiquette lessons for civil servents that deal with the public, or a call to civic leaders to push for more respectful behavior.
Strangely I was always taught to be courteous and polite to people. Why are lessons promotions courses etc now considered necessary ?
